head.title: Half Revival, Half Rockers, But Proselytizing Throughout

hedline.hl1: Half Revival, Half Rockers, But Proselytizing Throughout

abstract.p: Ben Ratliff reviews concert of Nyabinghi, reggae-style music by Mystic Revelation of Rastafari, at New York Society for Ethical Culture (M)

block.p: Nyabinghi music is to reggae what campfire spirituals are to gospel, and the Mystic Revelation of Rastafari, performing on Monday night at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, delivered a concise, presentable version of it. They were partly re-enacting one of the religious conventions, called ''grounations,'' that they regularly hold in their West Kingston stronghold: Rastafarian revival meetings of dancing, singing, playing, cooking and worshiping that last for days.

The group has legendary status; an earlier incarnation of it led by a master percussionist named Count Ossie, who died in 1976, backed the Folkes Brothers on ''Oh Carolina'' in 1960, which was the first popular indigenous-sounding Jamaican recording and paved the way for reggae. It made a triple album in 1973, ''Grounation,'' mixing jazz-influenced horns with chanting and percussion, which is an obscure treasure among reggaephiles. But the nyabinghi style went beyond this particular band; Bob Marley recorded nyabinghi songs, and in the recent moral backlash against the hard sentiments and harder music of Jamaican dancehall-reggae, some of dancehall's own practitioners have gone back to the nyabinghi style to demonstrate their own live-and-let-live Rastafarian faith.

Nyabinghi music is to reggae what campfire spirituals are to gospel, and the Mystic Revelation of Rastafari, performing on Monday night at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, delivered a concise, presentable version of it. They were partly re-enacting one of the religious conventions, called ''grounations,'' that they regularly hold in their West Kingston stronghold: Rastafarian revival meetings of dancing, singing, playing, cooking and worshiping that last for days.

The group has legendary status; an earlier incarnation of it led by a master percussionist named Count Ossie, who died in 1976, backed the Folkes Brothers on ''Oh Carolina'' in 1960, which was the first popular indigenous-sounding Jamaican recording and paved the way for reggae. It made a triple album in 1973, ''Grounation,'' mixing jazz-influenced horns with chanting and percussion, which is an obscure treasure among reggaephiles. But the nyabinghi style went beyond this particular band; Bob Marley recorded nyabinghi songs, and in the recent moral backlash against the hard sentiments and harder music of Jamaican dancehall-reggae, some of dancehall's own practitioners have gone back to the nyabinghi style to demonstrate their own live-and-let-live Rastafarian faith.

Mystic Revelation of Rastafari had 12 members on Monday night, and its music was built on drumming -- a large bass drum striking the first beat, a group of cheap, military-style ramskin funde drums on the one and three, and a ''repeater'' drum improvising with syncopation on top of it. After a warm-up oration by the rasta poet Mutabaruka, the group filed on stage with their hands in plastic chains, singing ''By the Rivers of Babylon''; at the end of the song, they shot their arms in the air, broke the chains, and shouted ''Uhuru!''

Samuel Clayton, a singer and percussionists who doubled as announcer, followed with a short history of Jamaican slavery and a brief sermon on the purpose of Rastafarianism; he then explained that the group's set would be half grounation-music -- ''like a ground wire, a series of chants so that when things get rough you don't get shocked'' -- and half ''rockers.''

Through it all, the rhythms of the music came from burru and kumina, pre-slavery African rhythms; the drummers sat in a circle. In the ''grounation'' half, a guitarist gently played standard major chords, and the group members sang biblical language in two-part harmony. It was simple, sleepy music, sometimes rather crudely done. In the more pop-like ''rockers'' half, Anthony Arnold Brakenridge played the trumpet and Egbert Evans played the saxophone and flute, interjecting melody into the songs; Donovan Cunningham played repeating vamps on the electric bass, and as a whole it sometimes sounded like elementary imitations of New Orleans or Memphis rhythm-and-blues.

At odds with the self-consciously crude style was the group's presentation, finely honed for outsiders. The group hasn't played in New York before, but it has been touring Europe and has developed a demonstrative, pedantic stage show with strident politics, boosterism for Jamaican tourism and painted tchotchkes handed out to the crowd. It was probably a bit too clunky for this particular audience, many of whom were Rastafarians or at least the most devout of reggae aficionados.
